page.title: Post–World War II air-to-air combat losses

revision.comment: clean up; http→https for [[Google Books]] and other Google services using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:C-130 60528 MiG.JPG|thumb|right|The last moments of a U.S. Air Force recon [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130 Hercules]] in gun camera of the Soviet [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG-17]]. 1958.]] [[File:MiG-17 shoot down sequence 3 June 1967.jpg|thumb|alt=Gun camera sequence photo showing a North Vietnamese MiG-17-fighter being hit.|[[Gun camera]] sequence photos showing a North Vietnamese [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17|MiG-17]] being hit and shot down by 20 mm shells from a U.S. Air Force [[Republic F-105 Thunderchief|F-105D Thunderchief]] during the [[Vietnam War]].]] [[File:Nguyenvancoc.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Nguyễn Văn Cốc]], the most successful pilot of the [[Vietnam War]]. He shot down 11 aircraftBowers, Al; Lednicer, David (17 May 1999). "Fighter Pilot Aces List". The Air University.]] [[Air-to-air combat]] is the engagement of flying machines in [[warfare]] in which one or more aircraft tries to destroy one or more other aircraft. The Korean War saw the greatest amount of air-to-air combat since World War II. During the war the United States claimed to have shot down around 700 fighters.{{#tag:ref|During the [[Korean War]] experienced [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] pilots flew against USAF forces.{{harvnb|Brune|1996|p=215}}|group="A"}}{{harvnb|Dorr|Thompson|2003|p=186}} After the war the USAF reviewed its figures in an investigation code-named ''Sabre Measure Charlie'' and downgraded the kill ratio of the [[North American F-86 Sabre]] against the [[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15]] by half from 14:1 to 7:1. One of the factors inflating US numbers was that most dogfights took place over enemy-controlled area. The only way to confirm kills was through gun camera photography. USAF pilots were credited with a kill if the gun camera showed their guns striking the enemy aircraft even if no one actually saw it go down.{{harvnb|Zhang|2004|p=153}} However, Soviet kill claims were also highly exaggerated, based upon inherent flaws in their film grading procedures. For instance, the S-13 gun camera was not aligned with either the gunsight or either cannons' ballistics. It ran only while the firing buttons were depressed. Film graders commonly included unit commanders and political commisars who would confirm a "kill"—sometimes even if one had not been claimed by a pilot—when the camera's crosshairs touched the target for two movie frames. During the first 16 months of combat Soviet V-VS units claimed 218 F-86s destroyed when only 36 (35 to the two elite IADs and one to the 50th IAD) had been lost. This results in a 600 per cent inflation rate in victory credits over actual Sabres destroyed. The [[Vietnam War]] saw a move away from cannon fire to air-to-air missiles.{{harvnb|Boyne|2002|p=2}} Although US forces maintained [[air supremacy]] throughout the war, there were still occasional dogfights and several US [[flying ace|aces]]. The North Vietnamese side claimed the [[Vietnam People's Air Force]] had [[List of Vietnam War flying aces|17 aces]] throughout the war, including Nguyen Van Coc, who is also the top ace of Vietnam War with nine kills: seven manned aircraft and two UAVs.{{clarify|post-text=Image caption says 11|date=September 2014}} During the 1947 conflict over [[Jammu and Kashmir (princely state)|Jammu and Kashmir]], the Indian Air Force did not engage the [[Pakistan Air Force]] in air-to-air combat; however, it did provide effective transport and close air support to the Indian troops.{{Harvnb|Barua|2005|p=192|Ref=Barua}} The [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]] was the first time the [[Indian Air Force]] actively engaged an enemy air force.{{Harvnb|Pradhan|Chavan|2007|p=xiv|Ref=ybChavan}} By the time the conflict had ended, India lost between 65 and 75 aircraft and Pakistan lost between 20 and 43.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2007/20070506/spectrum/main1.htm |title=The Sunday Tribune - Spectrum |publisher=Tribuneindia.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-09}}{{cite book|author=Thomas M. Leonard |title=Encyclopedia of the Developing World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pWRjGZ9H7hYC&pg=PA806|accessdate=14 April 2011 |year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-97663-3|page=806}} The [[Indian Air Force]] lost 45 aircraft during the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1971]] and the [[Pakistani Air Force]] lost 75 aircraft.https://books.google.com/books?id=gc2NAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA806&dq=pakistan+lost+aircrafts+1965&hl=en&sa=X&ei=d8abVfLbKpGOuATu1qi4BA&ved=0CBkQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=pakistan%20lost%20seventy%20five&f=false During the [[Iran–Iraq War]] of 1980–88, there were nearly 1,000 air-to-air engagements between Iran and Iraq, including the only known instances of helicopters dogfighting and shooting down other helicopters.{{cite web|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/persiancats.html |title=Persian Cats | Military Aviation |work=Air & Space Magazine |date= |accessdate=2013-08-09}} The [[Falklands War]] of 1982 witnessed air combat between Argentine and British military aircraft. The Falkland Islands' runways were short and thus unable to support fighter jets, forcing Argentina to launch fighters from the mainland, which had an adverse effect on their loiter time. The Argentine forces lost 23 aircraft in air-to-air combat, out of a total of 134 fixed wing aircraft and helicopters lost during the conflict. During the 1990–91 [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]] 33 of Iraq's 750 fixed wing aircraft were claimed as downed (23 were confirmed), compared to 14 coalition aircraft claimed as downed (the loss of one coalition [[F/A-18 Hornet]] is confirmed)."The First Night" by Cooper, Sadik (IAPR, Vol.26) ==Aircraft lost to air-to-air combat== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! Conflict ! Air Force ! "Operation Samarrah", October 2010 |-style="text-align:center;" |align=left| {{flagicon|Iraq}} [[Iraqi Air Force]] | 23 (Iraqi claim); 44 (Coalition claim) |{{harvnb|Davis|2002|p=300}} |-style="text-align:center;" |rowspan="2"|{{sort|1994| [[Iraqi no-fly zones]] enforcement}} |align=left| {{flagicon|US}} [[United States armed forces|US Aircraft]] | 3{{#tag:ref|The [[1994 Black Hawk shootdown incident]], sometimes referred to as the '''Black Hawk Incident''', was a [[friendly fire]] incident over northern [[Iraq]] that occurred on April 14, 1994 during [[Operation Provide Comfort]]. The pilots of two [[United States Air Force]] (USAF) [[F-15 Eagle|F-15]] [[fighter aircraft]], operating under the control of a USAF [[airborne warning and control system]] (AWACS) aircraft, misidentified two [[United States Army]] [[UH-60 Black Hawk]] [[helicopters]] as Iraqi [[Mil Mi-24]] "Hind" helicopters. The F-15 pilots fired on and destroyed both helicopters, killing all 26 military service members and civilians from the United States, United Kingdom, France, Turkey, and the [[Kurdish people|Kurdish community]]. The third loss was a UAV Predator shot down by a Mig-25 in December 2002.|group="A"}} |One [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|Predator]] was shot by a Mig-25 on December 27, 2002. Knights, Michael (2005).''Cradle of conflict: Iraq and the birth of modern U.S. military power''. Naval Institute Press, p. 242. ISBN 1-59114-444-2 |-style="text-align:center;" |align=left| {{flagicon|Iraq}} [[Iraqi Air Force]] | 5 | |-style="text-align:center;" | {{sort|Croatian War of Independence|[[Croatian War of Independence]] (1991–1995)}} |align=left| {{flagicon|Italy}} [[Italian Army]] |1{{#tag:ref|An [[Italian Army]] [[Bell 206]] helicopter [[1992 European Community Monitor Mission helicopter downing|was shot down by a Serb Mig]] over [[Novi Marof]], near [[Varaždin]], [[Croatia]], on 7 January 1992. One French and four Italian [[Military attaché|military observers]] were killed. The incident prompted the resignation of the Yugoslav Minister of Defence. The helicopter was part of an [[European Community]] mission in Croatia.|group="A"}} |[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/56184868.html?dids=56184868:56184868&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+09,+1992&author=&pub=USA+TODAY+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Yugoslav+defense+chief+resigns+after+attack&pqatl=google "Yugoslav defense chief resigns after attack"] ''[[USA today]]'', Jan 9, 1992 |-style="text-align:center;" | {{sort|1992|[[1992 Venezuelan coup d'état attempts]]}} |align=left| {{flagicon|Venezuela}} [[Revolutionary Bolivarian Movement-200|Bolivarianos]] | 3 |{{cite web|url=http://www.acig.org/artman/publish/article_161.shtml |title=Venezuela |publisher=ACIG |last1=Cooper |first1=Tom |last2=Sosa |first2=Juan |date=1 September 2003 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} |-style="text-align:center;" | {{sort|1994|[[Operation Deny Flight]]}} |align=left| [[File:Flag of Republika Srpska.svg|border|25px]] [[Republika Srpska Air Force]] | 5 |[http://www.avijacijabezgranica.com/jrvudesi.html ''Lista gubitaka/ostecenja vazduhoplova u Ex-JRV od 1945 godine do danas''] {{Sr icon}} |-style="text-align:center;" | {{sort|1995|[[Cenepa War]] (1995)}} |align=left| {{flagicon|Peru}} [[Peruvian Air Force]] | 1 (confirmed), 2 (Ecuadorian claim) |{{harvnb|Scheina|2003|p=125}} |-style="text-align:center;" | {{sort|1996|[[Aegean dispute]] (1996)}} |align=left| {{flagicon|Turkey}} [[Turkish Air Force]] | 1 |{{cite web|url=http://www.f-16.net/news_article619.html |title=Deadly 1996 Aegean clash is confirmed |publisher=F-16.net |date= |accessdate=2013-08-09}} |-style="text-align:center;" |rowspan="2"|{{sort|1998|[[Eritrean–Ethiopian War]] (1998–2000)}} |align=left| {{flagicon|Eritrea}} [[Eritrean Air Force]] | 2–6 |[http://www.worldaffairsboard.com/military-aviation/30162-flanker-vs-falcrum-ethiopia-vs-eritrea-what-actually-happened.html Flankervs Falcrum in Ethiopia vs. Eritrea.
